org.regenstrief.util
Class RegexTokenizer

java.lang.Object
  org.regenstrief.util.RegexTokenizer
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.regex.MatchResult
public class RegexTokenizer
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.regex.MatchResult

A kind of token iterator that allows one to clip a sequence of regular expression matches from a string.

Example, a tokenizer that would do some shallow XML parsing could look somewhat like this: 

    String REGEX = "<([/?!]?)([^ >]+)>|&(#?)([A-Za-z0-9]+);";
    int GROUP_ALL = 0;
    int GROUP_TAG_PREFIX = 1;
    int GROUP_TAG_NAME = 2;
    int GROUP_ENT_PREFIX = 3;
    int GROUP_ENT_NAME = 4;
    RegexTokenizer tokens = new RegexTokenizer(PSEUDO_XML_REGEX, xmlString);
    while(tokens.seek()) {
      String textNode = tokens.skipped();
      if(textNode != null) {
        // text node leading up to next tag
      }
      String tagName = tokens.group(GROUP_TAG_NAME);
      String entName = tokens.group(GROUP_ENT_NAME);
      if(tagName != null) {
        String tagPrefix = tokens.group(GROUP_TAG_PREFIX);
        if(tagPrefix == null) {
          // start element
        } else if(tagPrefix.equals("/")) {
          // end element
        }
      } else if(entName != null) {
        String entPrefix = tokens.group(GROUP_ENT_PREFIX);
        if(entPrefix == null) {
          if(entName.equals("amp")) {
            // the &amp; entity means the character &
          } else if(entName.equals("lt")) {
            // the &lt; entity means the character <
          } else ...
        } else if(entPrefix.equals("#")) {
          int char = Integer.parseInt(entName);
          // the character char
        }
      }
    }
    String textNode = tokens.rest();
    if(textNode) {
      // text node after last tag (or lone text node if there were no tags)
    }

Method Detail

seek

public boolean seek()
Finds the next matching token, skipping over any non-matching text. The non-matching text can be retrieved by the skipped property.

next

public boolean next()
Returns true if we are looking directly at a matching token, else returns false.

Returns the text that was skipped by the most recent seek operation.

rest

public java.lang.String rest()
Returns the rest of the string that has not yet been matched either because we did not try to match it using next or seek, or because a final seek had not found any further matching token.

group

public java.lang.String group(int i)
Returns a the capture-group, which relates to the parenthesis term in the regex. The group number 0 (zero) is the same as the entire token, 1 (one) is the first parenthesis term, etc.

Specified by:
group in interface java.util.regex.MatchResult

public int groupCount()
Returns the number of capture groups defined in the regex term.
